Author: peritonlogon#7708
Content: @dukeleto   I get that.  But if I'm trading into ARRR, the account I'm trading from IS transparent.  And if I'm trading out of ARRR the account I'm trading to IS transparent.  afaik most uses of crypto require transparency.  So, explaining to me how dividing zk-transparent into two chains is better than one requires more than just telling me how ARRR works, it requires explaining to me why it is better than being on 1 chain.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
@peritonlogon because of Z pool size and the fungiblility differences. When it's on one chain, someone can see 10 coins go into Z address, and 10 coins go out. If the pool is small enough (and it almost always is with t and Z chains) then this analysis is very effective at beating privacy.

Z pool size is a good way to protect against this, but still is only really effective if people send into the Z pool uniform amounts and leave them in the Z pool for random amounts of time. Jumblr was designed to do this actually, break balance into specific amounts (100, 10, etc) and send into z pool, and send out at random times, this way everyone's "in" and "outs" were the same sizes... but even still, the pool was too small to effectively mask transactions.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
Having it on a different chain means that not only is the Z pool nearly 99.9%, coins going "in" ie. Buying ARRR, don't have to come out as the same coin. 

So instead of KMD going to Z and the same amount of KMD coming out. Now you have N amount of BTC going into ARRR Z, and coming out as ETH, or KMD, or any other coin.

Content: Eventually, atomic swaps with ARRR will be like a massive, crypto agnostic Z pool for all coins to utilize.

Author: mrtzmp3#2896
Content: Can some one in the complete layman terms explain pls , npsv and private swaps

Author: mrtzmp3#2896
Content: And why it needed and unique to kmd

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
@mrtzmp3 nSPV - is a wallet type that is exclusive to the Komodo ecosystem. Traditional SPV wallets (lite wallets, like mobile, or websites) don't download the whole blockchain, but download the headers from the whole blockchain, if the headers all line up, it can be pretty sure that it's address/transactions are correct. This however downloads ALL the block headers, which can actually become quite a bit of data, especially as blockchains grow longer, and a wallet might handle dozens of coins.

nSPV does the same thing as SPV, except instead of downloading ALL of the headers, it pays particular attention to Notarizations (exclusive to Komodo) The wallet treats the notarization basically as the beginning of the chain, as it is infeasible for anyone to change the info before a notarization. This means nSPV wallets are hundreds, if not thousands of times more efficient than SPV wallets. It uses a tiny amount of RAM to verify transactions and makes it ideal for IoT and low computing power devices like watches.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: here is a more in depth (and better 😅 ) explanation <https://komodoplatform.com/nspv-next-generation-spv/>

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: `TLDR: nSPV is SPV but instead of downloading ALL the blockheaders, it only downloads them to the most recent Notarization, making it thousands of times more efficient`

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
adding to @Regnar 's explanation, one other major benefit of nSPV is that, a normal komodo full node can serve the data required by a nSPV wallet
this is in contrast to normal SPV wallets which need dedicated Electrum servers which can only take so much load (as the number of concurrent users increase, more Electrum servers are needed)
so nSPV tech helps in scalability(not in tps but in number of lite clients supported) too

p.s: Testing the capacity of the various Electrum servers used by AtomicDEX is one of the objectives of the upcoming stress test
